views.name: All staff members grouped by department

rows.field_51161: Procedure for integrating new employees into the company, ensuring they have the necessary tools, accounts, and orientation.
Standard process for receiving, logging, and resolving customer complaints.
Process for reviewing and approving purchase orders before execution.
Procedure to ensure daily backups of critical IT systems.
Standard process for recording, storing, and distributing meeting minutes.
Steps for employees to request reimbursement for work-related expenses.
Process to ensure stock levels are maintained at required quantities.
Procedure for updating, approving, and storing controlled documents.
Routine procedure for maintaining company equipment.
Steps to create, approve, and schedule official company social media posts.

rows.field_51169:
- Receive signed employment contract from employee.
- Scan and upload contract to HR system.
- Confirm digital record is stored securely.

- Add personal details to HR database. 
- Input payroll information. 
- Verify data accuracy against signed contract.

- Set up company email account. 
- Assign software licenses. 
- Configure and test access badge.

- Reserve orientation session date. 
- Send calendar invite to new hire. 
- Confirm attendance with HR trainer.

- Set up desk and chair. 
- Install and test computer equipment. 
- Provide starter kit (stationery, manuals).

- Record complaint in ticketing system. 
- Include customer details. 
- Assign a case reference number.

- Draft acknowledgment email.
- Confirm receipt with customer. 
- Provide estimated resolution time.

- Identify correct department to handle issue. 
- Forward ticket to responsible party. 
- Confirm receipt by assignee.

- Review complaint details. 
- Contact relevant staff for input. 
- Identify root cause of issue.

- Draft resolution response. 
- Explain findings to customer. 
- Confirm closure in ticketing system.

- Fill all required fields in PO form. 
- Attach supporting documents. 
- Submit to purchasing department.

- Verify supplier quote is attached. 
- Check product specs are correct. 
- Ensure compliance with policy.

- Check budget line in system. 
- Confirm funds availability. 
- Record verification in PO log.

- Review PO for accuracy. 
- Obtain signature from authorized person. 
- Save approval record.

- Email PO to supplier. 
- Request confirmation of receipt. 
- Update status in procurement system.

- Check backup destination is accessible.
- Start backup job in backup software.
- Ensure correct backup profile is selected.
- Verify backup job has started successfully (progress bar, job log entry).

- Verify file selection matches schedule. 
- Include all required databases. 
- Confirm completion without errors.

- Run integrity test on backup files.
- Check for corrupted files
- Document results in log

- Save backup log to secure folder. 
- Label log with date/time. 
- Restrict access to authorized users.

- Confirm offsite/cloud copy is present. 
- Test accessibility. 
- Record verification in log.

- Open meeting template. 
- Fill in meeting title and date.
- Add participant list.

- Record decisions made. 
- Document action points. 
- Summarize key discussion points.

- Check draft for completeness. 
- Correct typos and errors. 
- Verify all actions are recorded.

- Send draft to meeting chair. 
- Receive approval. 
- Save approved version.

- Email minutes to attendees.
- Store in shared repository. 
- Update meeting records.

- Fill expense form with details. 
- Include dates for each expense. 
- Indicate payment method used.

- Scan each receipt. 
- Attach files to claim form.
- Check readability of images.

- Use approval criterion checklist (policy-compliant expenses, full documentation, correct codes).
- Provide comments or notes if any adjustments are made.
- Assign alternate approver if original manager is unavailable.
- Mark as approved and move to next step.

- Enter approval date in system. 
- Upload manager's approval. 
- Mark claim as "approved."

- Send claim to finance. 
- Confirm payment is processed. 
- Notify employee of completion.

- Conduct physical count. 
- Record quantities in system. 
- Compare to last inventory record.

- Check against reorder thresholds. 
- Highlight low items in report. 
- Send report to purchasing.

- Complete restock request form. 
- Specify quantities needed. 
- Send to purchasing department.

- Receive order confirmation.
- Verify pricing matches quote. 
- Record expected delivery date.

- Compare delivery to PO. 
- Check item quality. 
- Update inventory system.

- Save old version in archive folder. 
- Add version number. 
- Restrict editing access.

- Create updated document. 
-  Highlight changes made.
- Save as draft.

- Send draft to owner. 
- Receive feedback. 
- Apply corrections.

- Send to authorized approver. 
- Obtain signed approval. 
- Save approval record.

- Place new version in repository. 
- Update version control log.
- Notify relevant staff.

- Retrieve maintenance checklist. 
- Verify equipment details match. 
- Prepare necessary tools.

- Complete all listed maintenance actions. 
- Lubricate moving parts. 
- Replace worn components.

- Write down faults found. 
- Include repair recommendations. 
- Add photos if needed.

- Sign maintenance log. 
- Add completion date. 
- Confirm work done.

- Store log in maintenance file. 
- Backup digital copy. 
- Notify supervisor.

- Write post text. 
- Create accompanying graphic. 
- Check alignment with brand guidelines.

- Submit draft to marketing lead. 
- Apply any suggested edits.
- Re-submit for approval.

- Send draft to legal if needed. 
- Address compliance feedback. 
- Save compliance approval.

- Get final sign-off. 
- Document approval date. 
- Archive approved version.

- Enter post in scheduling tool. 
- Verify time and date. 
- Confirm post is queued.

fields.name: Name
fields.formula: join(concat(lookup('Procedure step','Step name'),' (Step ',lookup('Procedure step','Step order'),' of ',lookup('Procedure step','Procedure'),' procedure)'),'')

views.name: All tasks grouped by procedure step
All tasks stacked by their status

rows.field_51179: The instructions for this step are mostly clear, but there are a few sections where examples would help, especially for first-time claimants. It’s obvious what to do overall, but the reimbursement codes could be listed in a quick-reference guide

rows.field_51179: The step is straightforward and I know exactly what’s required, but it would be useful to have a reminder of acceptable file types before uploading.
rows.field_51180: For my train tickets to go the AI conference

rows.field_51179: The purpose of this step is obvious, but I’m not sure if my manager always knows the criteria for approval. A short checklist might help them stay consistent.
rows.field_51180: For my train tickets to go the AI conference

rows.field_51179: It’s clear that this step is about formal confirmation, but I don’t fully understand what’s being checked at this stage. More detail would make it easier to trust the process.
rows.field_51180: For my train tickets to go the AI conference

rows.field_51179: This step is clear, and I know it’s the final stage, but it would help if there was an estimated completion time posted when it starts.
rows.field_51180: For my train tickets to go the AI conference

rows.field_51179: I understood the purpose of the form, but the layout could be more intuitive. I had to scroll back and forth between sections to check I’d filled in everything correctly.

rows.field_51179: This step is clear, but the instructions could be more specific about whether original paper receipts are still needed after uploading digital copies.
rows.field_51180: My entrance ticket for the conference

rows.field_51179: Clear in theory, but when managers are busy the review can be delayed, which slows the whole process. Maybe a secondary reviewer could be assigned if deadlines are tight.
rows.field_51180: My entrance ticket for the conference

rows.field_51179: I know what to do here—which is essentially nothing—but I would appreciate a clearer indication of when it’s completed, so I don’t have to check back manually.
rows.field_51180: My entrance ticket for the conference

rows.field_51179: The action required here is straightforward, but sometimes I’m unsure if I need to confirm my payment details before it’s processed.
rows.field_51180: My entrance ticket for the conference

rows.field_51179: The step is manageable in its current size, but it could be split into two smaller parts—basic personal details first, then expense details—to make it feel less overwhelming
rows.field_51180: 3 nights in the Model hotel during the conference

rows.field_51179: The task is small enough to be quick, but sometimes I wish it was combined with Step 1 so I can submit everything at once instead of going back into the system twice.
rows.field_51180: 3 nights in the Model hotel during the conference

rows.field_51179: The step is about the right size, but it might benefit from including a quick comment field for managers to explain any adjustments they make.
rows.field_51180: 3 nights in the Model hotel during the conference

rows.field_51179: This step could potentially be merged with Manager Review if the approvals are always sequential and involve the same checks.
rows.field_51180: 3 nights in the Model hotel during the conference

rows.field_51179: The step is the right size, but it might be worth adding an automatic notification once payment is complete to close the loop.
rows.field_51180: 3 nights in the Model hotel during the conference

rows.field_51179: This step is generally clear in its purpose, but the instructions could benefit from more context on how to verify that the backup has started successfully. Currently, it only states to initiate the backup, which may leave room for error if an operator assumes pressing a single button is sufficient. A short checklist or confirmation prompt might prevent partial or failed starts. It could also be beneficial to include a pre-check to ensure the backup destination is accessible before proceeding.

The step is functionally sound, but it feels broad since “files” and “databases” may require different procedures or tools. If the backup process for databases involves specialized scripts or configurations, those should be detailed or referenced here. Splitting this step into two could also make it easier to isolate failures and troubleshoot when issues occur.

This is a crucial step, but “check integrity” is too general and might be interpreted differently by different people. The method (checksum comparison, file size verification, database consistency check) should be specified. Providing acceptable thresholds for passing the integrity check would make the step more actionable and reduce subjective judgment.

Storing the log is a good practice, but it’s unclear where exactly it should be stored, in what format, and who should have access. Standardizing the storage location and naming convention could prevent confusion and ensure traceability. It might also be worth automating this step to reduce the chance of human error.

The step’s goal is important, but “verify” should be clearly defined — does this mean confirming file presence, checking transfer success logs, or testing file restorability? Additionally, if the offsite copy is stored in a cloud environment, guidelines for accessing audit logs or retrieval tests should be provided.

Counting inventory is clear, but the frequency and method could be better specified. Manual counting may introduce errors, and the step might benefit from referencing barcode scanners or inventory software. If partial counts are acceptable, that should be noted to save time without reducing accuracy.

This step assumes the user knows the reorder threshold, but it would be safer to explicitly reference the predefined restocking levels. Including a method for identifying potential stockouts before they happen (e.g., based on historical sales patterns) could make the process more proactive.

This step is straightforward but should include guidance on the approval workflow, preferred format (e.g., email, system ticket), and required details (SKU, quantity, urgency). Without these, restock requests might be delayed due to incomplete information.

Confirmation is important, but it would be better if this step included instructions on what exactly to confirm — price, quantity, delivery date, and payment terms. It should also suggest documenting the confirmation in a shared system for transparency.

This step ensures the final result but could be strengthened by including guidelines for quality inspection upon arrival. Simply counting the items may not be sufficient if defective products are accepted. Adding a note about updating inventory systems immediately after verification would close the loop.

Opening the checklist is an appropriate starting point, but it would help to state where the checklist is stored and ensure it’s up to date. If multiple versions exist, clear version control instructions should be included.

This is the core step, but it is too general. Detailed sub-steps or references to maintenance manuals would ensure consistency. Different equipment types may require specific attention, so linking to relevant procedures could reduce errors.

The intention here is good, but it might be useful to define what qualifies as an “issue” and what level of detail is required in the record. A structured reporting format could make it easier to spot recurring problems over time.

Signing the log is straightforward, but it should be clear whether this is a physical signature, a digital acknowledgment, or both. Including a timestamp and technician ID would further improve accountability.

Filing is necessary, but specifying where the records should be stored (physical cabinet, cloud storage, maintenance software) will prevent misplacement. Access permissions should also be considered, especially if the logs contain sensitive operational details.

The step is clear but should also specify who is responsible for ensuring the employee receives a signed copy. Including a digital storage location with restricted access would improve compliance and data security.

Data entry needs to be precise, and this step could be improved by specifying which systems to update (HRIS, payroll, benefits portal) and what mandatory fields are required. Double-checking for data entry errors should be encouraged.
The purpose is clear, but guidelines for account permissions, security settings, and password policies would ensure consistency and compliance with IT security standards.

This step is fine but could include details on the expected content of the orientation, who should deliver it, and whether it should be in-person or virtual. Sending a calendar invite with all relevant details should be part of the process.

Preparing the workstation is good practice, but a checklist of required items (hardware, software, access cards) would ensure no key element is missed. Including a step to test the setup before the employee arrives would avoid delays.

The step is generally clear, but it could benefit from specifying exactly what fields are mandatory versus optional in the complaint form. Sometimes staff are unsure whether attachments are required at this stage. A checklist for data completeness before submission would reduce back-and-forth corrections. Otherwise, the logging process is easy to follow and works well

The step is straightforward and ensures the customer feels heard, which is positive. However, it would help to provide a template with customizable fields to avoid inconsistent wording across departments. Timing expectations (e.g., within 24 hours) should be reinforced so staff don’t delay. Staff appreciate that this step improves customer trust but would welcome clearer guidelines

The process works, but sometimes staff hesitate about which department owns responsibility when issues cross functional areas. A decision tree or examples of typical complaint categories would make this step more reliable. In most cases, the assignment is fast, but occasional misrouting leads to delays. Adding validation rules in the system could prevent errors.

This step is the most resource-intensive, and while instructions are clear, they might be too broad. Staff recommend breaking down the investigation process into sub-tasks (e.g., collect evidence, interview staff, review system logs). Without this, some employees approach the investigation inconsistently, leading to uneven quality. That said, employees find the flexibility useful in complex cases

The resolution step is handled fairly well, and customers often respond positively. One improvement would be to include guidance on tone and structure of the message, especially for sensitive complaints. A standardized template would save time and ensure consistent professionalism. Staff also suggested including a reminder to ask for customer feedback at this stage, which could improve overall process evaluation

The instructions for counting inventory are clear, but the process can be time-consuming when dealing with large stock volumes. Staff suggest implementing barcode scanners or digital tally tools to speed up the process and minimize human error. Additionally, having clearer guidelines on how to handle discrepancies (e.g., missing or damaged items) would help reduce confusion. On the positive side, employees appreciate that this step provides a reliable foundation for the restocking workflow and ensures accountability

This step works fairly well, but staff sometimes feel uncertain about the exact thresholds for what qualifies as ‘low stock.’ Defining clearer minimum stock levels for each category would avoid unnecessary requests or late replenishments. It might also help to introduce automated alerts when stock reaches these thresholds, reducing manual monitoring. Overall, the step is seen as logical and important, but more precision would make it easier for employees to act quickly and confidently.

Submitting the restock request is a straightforward task, but some employees find that the request form lacks important fields, such as urgency level or justification for larger-than-usual quantities. Including these options could improve supplier planning and prevent delays. Staff also recommend providing examples of well-completed requests, which would help new employees understand expectations. Despite these small improvements, the current process is generally well-received, and most staff find it easy to execute.

The confirmation process is functional but could be enhanced by providing more transparency about supplier timelines and expected delivery dates. Staff sometimes feel left in the dark while waiting for confirmation, which creates uncertainty in planning. An automated acknowledgment from suppliers or an internal tracking tool would reduce the need for follow-up emails. Employees value this step because it creates accountability, but they agree it could be streamlined to save time

Verifying the arrival of stock is generally clear, but there are opportunities for improvement. Employees suggest adding a checklist for quality inspection (e.g., checking packaging integrity, expiration dates, or quantity accuracy), as these details are sometimes overlooked. In addition, having a digital log of verification outcomes would improve traceability in case of supplier disputes. On the positive side, staff find this step straightforward and important for closing the loop on the restocking process.

views.name: All suggestions grouped by proposed action
All suggestions stacked by their status

rows.field_51183: Multiple users report that the 'Complete Claim Form' step is overwhelming, could be more intuitive, and would benefit from separation into personal details and expense details. Examples and a reference to reimbursement codes are requested.
rows.field_51184:
- Users want examples and a quick-reference for reimbursement codes.
- The current form layout is not intuitive; suggest splitting into 'personal details' then 'expense details'.
- Generally clear, but splitting into two steps would help new users and prevent mistakes.
rows.field_51192: Enter Personal Details in Claim Form
rows.field_51193:
- Fill in all required personal and contact details.
- Confirm accuracy with official records.
- Check mandatory fields are completed.
- Reference quick-guide for reimbursement codes as needed.
rows.field_51195:
- List each expense with date and purpose.
- Attach relevant reimbursement code for each item.
- Double-check total amount matches attached receipts.
- Save and prepare for document upload.

rows.field_51183: There is no feedback available for this step. Without negative reports or suggestions, the current implementation should remain.
Most users find the step easy but request reminders on acceptable file types and clarification about whether original paper receipts must be kept post-upload.
rows.field_51184:
- Task is clear and manageable.
- Users want a list of accepted file types.
- Need explicit instruction on what to do with originals after upload.
rows.field_51187:
- Scan each receipt.
- Attach files (PDF, JPG, or PNG) to claim form.
- Ensure all images are readable.
- Retain original paper receipts until payment is confirmed (unless instructed otherwise).

rows.field_51183: There is no feedback available. The step falls within standard HR onboarding and does not show evidence of confusion.
While the review expectation is clear, managers are unsure about criteria and feel inconsistent. Suggestions include a checklist and comment field.
rows.field_51184:
- Managers want an approval checklist.
- Secondary reviewer option requested if manager unavailable.
- Comment field would enable transparency on adjustments.
rows.field_51187:
- Use approval criterion checklist (policy-compliant expenses, full documentation, correct codes).
- Provide comments or notes if any adjustments are made.
- Assign alternate approver if original manager is unavailable.
- Mark as approved and move to next step.

rows.field_51183: No feedback is documented for this step. It appears to be well-formed and clear.
Users are unclear what is being checked at this approval/log step and want more detail. Some feedback suggests merging steps, but reviews are often by different people so separation is kept.
rows.field_51184:
- Clarity needed about what is approved and what logs are required.
- Merge suggestion exists, but different roles often involved.
- Desire for visible progress/completion signals.
rows.field_51187:
- Enter approval date and approver name in system.
- Upload digital or scanned approval document.
- Notify claimant that their expense has been approved and claim status advanced.

rows.field_51183: Lack of provided feedback. No evidence or indication of needed change.
Step is generally clear, but users want expected payment timeline and confirmation to avoid unnecessary follow-ups. Unsure if their payment details need reconfirmation.
rows.field_51184:
- Add completion time estimate when starting payment process.
- Notify employee when payment is sent.
- Add prompt to confirm payment details if required.
rows.field_51187:
- Confirm employee banking/payment details on file or request them if missing.
- Process payment and record transaction in system.
- Notify employee when payment has been sent including expected date of deposit.

rows.field_51183: No documented problems. Step remains as originally designed.
Step is clear but lacks detail on verifying backup job has truly started and ensuring backup destination is accessible. Confirmation and a pre-check step are suggested.
rows.field_51184:
- Need to verify backup is running—not just started.
- Suggest pre-check on backup destination accessibility.
- Add confirmation/cue for successful start.
rows.field_51187:
- Check backup destination is accessible.
- Start backup job in backup software.
- Ensure correct backup profile is selected.
- Verify backup job has started successfully (progress bar, job log entry).

rows.field_51183: No execution feedback available for this step. Retain as is.
The original combined step creates ambiguity, as file and database backups may require different tools and procedures. Splitting helps isolate failures and clarify process.
rows.field_51184:
- 'Files' and 'databases' require differing procedures.
- Staff want detail or references for each.
- Splitting makes troubleshooting easier.
rows.field_51193:
- Confirm correct file backup selection per schedule.
- Run file backup using designated tool.
- Check for errors and confirm completion.
rows.field_51195:
- Select the appropriate database(s) for backup.
- Execute backup script or use admin tool as specified.
- Confirm successful backup and capture log for review.

rows.field_51183: No feedback; instructions are standard and straightforward.
'Check integrity' is too general and needs to specify the methods and pass/fail criteria.
rows.field_51184:
- Methods for integrity check are unclear.
- Specify checksum, size, or consistency tests needed.
- Define what constitutes a successful check.
rows.field_51187:
- Run file/database integrity checks using designated tool.
- Use checksum, file size, or consistency reports.
- Confirm all checks are within acceptable tolerance.
- Record results and flag any discrepancies.

rows.field_51183: No feedback present. The instructions are typical for an escalation step.
The storage location, format, and access protocols for backup logs are not specified. Standardization and automation are recommended.
rows.field_51184:
- Specify exact log location, naming convention, and secure access.
- Suggest automating or systematizing the process.
rows.field_51187:
- Save backup log in designated secure directory (define path/formats).
- Use standardized naming convention (YYYYMMDD_BackupType).
- Restrict access to authorized personnel.
- Confirm successful saving and restrict changes.

rows.field_51183: No available feedback to indicate issues or improvements.
Verification method for offsite copies is under-defined. Should clarify exactly how to verify presence, accessibility, or restorability.
rows.field_51184:
- Define steps: presence, log review, retrieval test, or restore trial?
- Offer cloud-specific audit or logging steps if applicable.
- Reduce ambiguity in 'verification' process.
rows.field_51187:
- Check offsite/cloud backup presence and timestamp.
- Review transfer success or audit logs.
- Perform test retrieval or file restore if possible.
- Record verification results in system log.

rows.field_51183: Absence of feedback suggests the step operates as expected.
Step is clear, but could be improved with more efficient tools (barcodes, digital tallies), clear instructions for discrepancies, and specifying partial count options.
rows.field_51184:
- Counting protocol is clear.
- Recommend adopting barcode/digital tools.
- Add policy for missing/damaged stock; clarify if partial counts allowed.
rows.field_51187:
- Use barcode scanner or digital tally where possible.
- Record all quantities in system per current count procedure.
- Note and segregate missing or damaged items for further review.
- If allowed, record scope of any partial counts.

rows.field_51183: There is no submitted feedback for this step.
Staff want clearer restocking thresholds/minimums and automated alerts when items drop below these levels.
rows.field_51184:
- Clarify and document reorder thresholds for all products.
- Automate alerts if possible.
- Step is logical but would benefit from specificity.
rows.field_51186: Identify Low Stock Based on Thresholds
rows.field_51187:
- Compare inventory levels against documented minimums.
- Highlight products below threshold for restock report.
- Initiate alert in system (if automation available).
- Send report to purchasing.

rows.field_51183: Lacking feedback reports; no improvements are currently justified.
Step is generally easy to follow but lacks guidance on required request details (urgency, SKU, justification), preferred submission format, and workflow for approval. Examples help new users.
rows.field_51184:
- Request form lacks urgency and justification fields.
- Add guidance on approval and submission format.
- Provide example requests for clarity.
rows.field_51187:
- Complete restock request form, including SKU, quantity, urgency, and justification if applicable.
- Attach any supporting documentation.
- Submit request via official system or email as preferred.
- Follow approval workflow and retain request until confirmation.

rows.field_51183: No feedback provided; the step appears clear and functional.
Step works, but more detail about what to confirm (price, quantity, timeline) and request digital confirmation from supplier/internal system. Add tracking.
rows.field_51184:
- Define what to confirm with supplier.
- Suggest documenting confirmation and expected delivery in a trackable format.
- Request for improved transparency and automated acknowledgment.
rows.field_51187:
- Receive and verify supplier order confirmation (price, quantity, payment terms, expected delivery).
- Document confirmation and attach to order record in shared tracking system.
- Notify purchasing and relevant departments.

rows.field_51183: No available staff input or concerns to act upon.
Verifying arrival is clear, but staff want explicit checklist for quality checks, instructions to update inventory system, and digital traceability.
rows.field_51184:
- Add packaging, quality, and accuracy checks.
- Digital log needed for traceability.
- Ensure inventory system is always updated immediately after check.
rows.field_51186: Verify Arrival and Complete Quality Check
rows.field_51187:
- Count items and check against PO.
- Perform visual and quality inspection (packaging, expiry, damage).
- Log verification in digital system with timestamp and responsible staff.
- Immediately update inventory records and close restocking task.

rows.field_51183: Without supporting feedback for change, the step remains as is.
No feedback, and step instructions are standard for IT backups.
No feedback was given, retain since the steps and checklist are standard.
No feedback reports; the instructions are already clear for the task.
No suggestions or negative reports received.
